div.head:
Embleme 28. Of the Secrets of Nature.
The King sitting in a vaporous bath is bathed, and freed from
melancholy by Pharut.

lg.l: Prince Duenech, armed with the Lyons strength,
Grew melancholickemelancholic and morose at length:
Pharut is sent for to contrive a cure,
Who by a vaporous bath doth health assure;
Which means by frequent use wrought good effect,
And his distempers wholy did correct.

div.head: Discourse 3.
div.ab:
As there are three concoctions in man, the first in the Stomacke, the second
in the Liver, the third in the veins, soe allso soe many are the universall-
evacuations of the excrements, which are correspondent to them, and daily
carry of their superfluityessuperfluities, namely the first by StooleStool, which is proper to
the first concoction, the second by urine, which appertainesappertains to the second,
the third by expiration through the pores of the whole body, or by-
seat, which is peculiar to the third: In the first the Chyle, in the next the-
Chyme, in the last a dew or dewy substance is elaborated, and applyed to-
every part of the body: The recrements or fæces of the first are thicke,
bilious, and fatt, which are carryed through the bowells to the backe dooredoor,
and if they be at any time obstructed, they are moderately or strongly
expelled by gentle purgatives; the excrements of the second are liquid,-
more thinne, bilious and saltish, which are brought out of the veins by
the kidnyeskidneys and bladder, as conduits, and the sediment of these is the signe
or touchstone of urine: The superfluityes of the third are yet more-
thinne, and therefore doe for the most part expire of themselves-
through the smallest pores, or are carryed out together with the serum of
the humors, as sweat: These are helpdhelped by sudorificks, as the antecedent by-
diureticks: To evacuate these last fæces the ancient Greeks and Romans-
were very solicitous: For to this end were soe many sports and exercises used
by them, as chafing of all the parts in the morning, anoyntinganointing with oyle,-
and wrasthingwrestling, fencing, the exercise of running, of hand=ball, tennicetennis, dai
ly washing and bathing in rivers or artificiall baths, for the conveniency
of which were soe many magnificent structures built at Rome, that wee
can rather admire than imitate them: As for example the baths of Dio
clesian, which for the most part are yet remaining, and (if I be not-
mistaken) pourtrayedportrayed with ArchangellsArchangels, soe high, sumptuous, and splendid
were the workes: The sorts of concoctions in the elaboration of metalls are-
allmost the saine, as those aforesaydaforesaid: for the first is in its way effected-
in annus magnus, that is, the revolution of the highest Sphere, the se
cond in the revolution of the lowest, the third in the revolution of the
midle Sphere: But the Philosophers to draw forth this masse of excrementitious
superfluityes more comodiously by the ministery of art, doe invent allso-
severall wayes, as ablutions, purgations, balneations and and laconickslaconics, by which
they have performd that in the Philosophicall worke, which Physicians
have in mans body: Duenech therefore is introduced into the bath by-
Pharut, there to sweat, and evacuate the fæces of the third concoction-
through the pores: Now this Kings distemper is melancholicke or atrabilary,-
whereby hee is of lesse authority and esteeme than all other princes, being
taxed with the morosity of Saturne, and the choler or passion of Mars:-
hee hath therefore a desire either to dye or be cured, if it be possible:-
Amongst many Physicians one being found, who undertookeundertook this charge
Discourse 28.
upon himselfe, hee was brought with entreatyesentreaties and rewards: And this Allegory
is very frequent in the writings of the Philosophers, as of Bernard, Alanus, in the
treatise of Duenech, and innumerable others; wee therefore add noe other cir
cumstances which might be derived from them: it is sufficient here to have ob
served, the excrement of which coction may be evacuated by balneation: for
herein consists the substance of the whole matter: Heat included in the body
is comonly reduced to the superficies of the skinne together with the blood in
hott stoves or baths, whereby a beautifull complexion is acquired to the face-
and whole body; which if it appear, will be a signe, that the melancholicke
blacknesse, which infects the skinne, may by degrees be evacuated, and all
the humors corrected, that pure and rosy blood may afterwards be genera
ted: The whole temperament of his body must necessarily be amended,-
because it resists good blood, and is cold and dry, that on the contrary being
hott and moist, which whether it can be done or noe, it is convenient for
a physician to foreknow and foretell by prognosticksprognostics: Some men are found
who have taken Cerdon for the great Prince or Kings Sonne, but they have-
at length by certaine signs perceived what hee was in descent and educa
tion: lest this should happen, the artist must be carefull in the first place
to choose the true offspring of the King, which though hee be not in splen
did and golden attire, but in despicable and meane cloathing, as allso of a-
livid and melancholicke complexion, let him not therefore reject him, or-
take another in his roome; for if hee be very well washd, his royallroyal ge
nius will soone appear, as in Cyrus, Paris, Romulus, who were educated-
amongst rusticks: But by way of observation the bath must be a LaconickeLaconics,-
that is, vaporous and sudorificke, that the water may not burne his tender flesh, or
obstruct the pores, whereby more damage than utility would ensue, and his malady
not be cured: As for the Kings garments to be put on after bathing let noe man
be solicitous; for as the daughter of King Alcinous did in times past contribute-
cloaths to Ulysses being shipwreckd and naked, soe will there be one that will-
send him most pretiousprecious robes, that hee may deservedly be acknowledged the-
Sonne of Sol. . . . . . . . . . . . .
